text: there's been some fascinating research
to suggest that when we play games and
we tap into positive emotions like
curiosity and optimism and creativity
and and even love that these emotions
actually stay with us for up to 24 hours
after we finish playing the game so
Studies have shown that we're more
likely to cooperate with someone in our
real lives after we've played a social
game with them where we're doing some
kind of Cooperative Mission or we're
more likely to set an ambitious goal for
ourselves after we've succeeded in a
game we'll we'll speak up more for
ourselves we'll even flirt with more
attractive strangers so there's this
kind of transfer of our confidence of
our creativity of our of our ambition to
our real lives we have this idea that
playing games is kind of a waste of time
um that it's not a very productive way
to spend our time and I kept hearing
that even as I was evangelizing in all
of the benefits of gaming the emotional
benefits the social the psychological
benefits people kept saying Yeah but
it's it's just a waste of time shouldn't
we be doing something more productive
than you know avenging some Angry Birds
and it really made me wonder well what
do we mean by productive I mean
productivity is about producing
something what do we really want to
produce more of in our lives and in the
lives of the people around us you know
are we trying to produce more emails or
you know are we trying to produce more
positive emotion are we trying to
produce stronger relationships are we
trying to produce a sense of meaning and
purpose and it turns out that games are
actually quite good at producing those
things that's what they produce more of
and better than almost anything else so
when people say games are a waste of
time and not productive I would
challenge them to ask themselves what do
you want to produce more of and if it's
things like better relationships and
more positive emotion in my daily life
then games might be the most productive
thing you can do
